instruction: How does COVID function as a chronic condition rather than just an acute infection?
response: Because initial COVID waves had such a massive death toll, that's what people think of when they hear 'COVID.' But it's more useful to view it like a chronic condition, in the same vein as AIDS coming out of HIV infection, or MS coming from Epstein-Barr virus. It's a multi-system affliction, not just a respiratory infection. Cardiovascular, neurological, and - crucially - immune damage are the real 'goal' of SARS-CoV-2. The respiratory system is just its route into the body. It sets up shop all over your body and evades immune detection. The effects of ignoring this 'invisible' stage of chronic disease progression will continue to accumulate in society. It will be more insidious than even AIDS, due to its respiratory route. Even if the acute stage gets less deadly, more deaths and disability will rack up. Many clinicians - and definitely all public officials - will fail to attribute ever-increasing rates of death and disability to the pandemic of yesteryear. It'll be chalked up to 'unknown etiology.' Scientists will expose real causes for decades, constantly ignored. This mass chronic illness will be the backdrop of coming climate change upheaval. Ascendant global fascism will harden further in face of mass migrations from disaster-ravaged regions. It's not 'lack of discipline' that precludes 'self-improvement' - if you got COVID and now experience chronic fatigue, your biochemistry has been altered. Your muscles literally break down in response to exertion. The problem isn't that you're not working hard enough.

instruction: What are the key protection numbers for COVID safety?
response: 95 refers to the N95 mask's ability to filter at least 95% of airborne particulates of at least 0.3 microns—the grade considered acceptable for reducing SARS-CoV-2 transmission. 6 is the feet apart recommended for preventing aerosolized droplets from reaching another person. 10 is the air changes per hour recommended for proper ventilation and dispersal. 15 is the minutes considered safe in someone's vicinity when other standards are met. Unmasked, non-distanced, and unventilated conditions drop this to 0. Even when wearing masks, 6 feet apart, in a well-ventilated room, spending more than 15 minutes with someone means you're rolling the dice that they don't have COVID.

instruction: Why is COVID not 'airborne HIV' but still dangerous?
response: SARS-CoV-2 is not 'airborne HIV' because it's not a retrovirus. It doesn't have reverse transcriptase; it can't insert itself into your genome. However, it doesn't need to. It doesn't change your genome, but it does change gene expression. Where HIV makes a permanent home in immune cells, SARS2 makes something like a temporary barricade—locks itself in, pumps out offspring, then eventually gets destroyed. But SARS2 is very good at keeping those bases going with a terror campaign. It forces cells to flood the area with warning signals, driving counter-insurgency forces crazy. T-cells become permanently activated, reserves get depleted, 'innocent' cells get caught in crossfire. Meanwhile, the virus quietly sends the next wave. It's its OWN type of immunodeficiency syndrome. And yes, it's much more transmissible.

instruction: How does ORF8 make SARS-CoV-2 particularly dangerous?
response: ORF8 is a SARS-CoV-2 gene associated with severity in both acute and persistent phases. ORF8 mutants don't cause as much harm. Researchers demonstrated that ORF8 encodes a protein that mimics histones—the proteins that package DNA and regulate which genes are expressed. Your cells use histones to regulate gene expression; if DNA is tightly packed with histones, your cell generally can't express those genes. SARS-CoV-2's ORF8 protein mimics histones, meaning on a molecular level, it affects gene expression in its hosts. We already knew the virus affected gene expression without knowing how. This explains the mechanism of much of COVID's damage.

instruction: What is the personal experience of long COVID like?
response: My life is a constant cycle of completely crashing after the 'exertion' of a typical work week—not even physically demanding, just being out and about. My second COVID infection has had significant neurological impact. I've always had some focus issues, but now it's completely ridiculous. I haven't been able to sit down to write since that infection. My thoughts have become disjointed. I have trouble staying on topic, recalling small details, starting and finishing tasks, and fully elucidating thoughts in a clear way. I still have analytical ability and creative heft—I haven't become 'dumber.' But I struggle to focus more than ever. Tasks have become too slippery to hold. Don't get COVID, kids.

instruction: How does COVID risk differ from other risks people accept?
response: The main differences are transmissibility, novelty, magnitude, and commonality. Transmissibility: You can't transmit Lyme disease or horse riding injury to someone else by breathing on them. Novelty and magnitude: Long COVID can affect every organ system, lasts as long as we've tracked it, has symptoms ranging from mild cough to unable to get out of bed. We don't know risk factors, disease progression, or damage extent with each infection. Clues point to very serious chronic condition with accumulating severity. Commonality: The risk is cumulative with every dice roll. COVID is everywhere with almost a billion confirmed cases. The chance of never getting infected without precautions is practically 0. Even at 10% long COVID rate, potentially hundreds of millions of cases already.

instruction: What is the significance of JN.1 (Janus) in COVID evolution?
response: JN.1 is the new omicron. Just as omicron was as distinct from SARS-CoV-2 as SARS-CoV-2 was from SARS, Pirola (BA.2.86) is again as distinct from omicron as omicron was from the original strain. JN.1, descended from Pirola, balanced distinctiveness with transmissibility. Unless you've already been infected with it, your immune system is essentially completely naive to it. It's more transmissible than its parent and driving the largest increase in cases and hospitalizations since omicron itself. There have only been 3 true 'waves' of COVID: initial emergence, omicron's rise, and JN.1. The evolutionary landscape is being rewritten, and almost certainly all new major variants will spawn from JN.1. I call it Janus—the Roman god of transitions, endings and new beginnings.

instruction: What is the difference between antivirals and vaccines for COVID?
response: Treatments like Paxlovid are protease inhibitors that prevent virus replication but don't kill it. Normally preventing replication would end infection, but SARS-CoV-2 is special—it can lay in wait then resume activities. After normal treatment course, the drug degrades and virus can resurge. This is why Biden tested positive again soon after testing negative. The virus evades immune detection by suppressing the 'Hey, there's a virus in here!' MHC pathway—which is also why vaccines aren't very good at preventing transmission. Once the virus sets up shop, it can stay undetected and spread at leisure. The most powerful tools remain: tightly-sealed respirators, air filtration, contact tracing, and quarantining until completely clear.
